Award.AbstractNarration:
This research moves towards walking and running robots that will meet and exceed the agility, efficiency, and robustness of human walking and running. Specifically, the research will address fundamental principles behind the physical design of legs, including describing configurations of joints, springs, and other components to best enable legged locomotion. This work falls within a broad, interdisciplinary effort to understand leg function and dynamics, and will have utility and impact among the robotics, dynamics, and biomechanics communities. The foundational design guidelines initiated here will enable robots that can go anywhere that animals and humans go, and many places they cannot, such as nuclear power plant disaster areas and burning buildings. The same foundation will enable prosthetic limbs and exoskeletons that match the natural dynamics of a human leg, while running all day on a single battery charge.

This research will enhance understanding of the interaction between the design of a legged system and its dynamics during touchdown, stance, and swing, focusing on three key aspects of the design: First, the inertia distribution in the leg, with an emphasis on how mass placement, number of links, and "redundant" elements of leg kinematics (such as pointing the knee "up" or "down") contribute to the impact felt by the system at touchdown and the dynamics during swing phase. Second, the motor coupling to the linkages, focusing on how different mappings between actuation and mechanism degrees of freedom can lead to the motors either sharing loads or fighting against each other. Third, spring function and placement, including desirable nonlinearities for mitigation of impacts and swing-phase ringing, alignment of principle stiffness axes with mechanism degrees of freedom, and transmissions that allow for configuration-dependent elasticity. The research approach draws on examples from biology and previously constructed robots, utilizes mathematical tools from applied mechanics, and builds on prior work with experimental walking and running robots.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Effective design and control of robotic legs is a key step in constructing robots that can go anywhere that humans or animals can go, robots that can go places where humans cannot go (e.g. nuclear accident sites or burning buildings), and exoskeletons or prosthetics that enhance human mobility.

 

This research focused on aspects of leg design that support the design and control of lightweight robot legs that comply with the surfaces they interact with. These features support both energy efficiency and preventing the robot from damaging surfaces it traverses.

 

Specific topics that we investigated included

 

1. Motor placement. Attaching motors to different sets of joints in the leg affects how they work together during leg motions. We found that the optimal motor placement depends on the commanded walking motion (not only the leg mechanism), and developed tools for placing the leg motors to support specific expected walking patterns.

 

2. Pulleys. Efficient and soft-contact walking motions often benefit from the transmission ratio between the motors and the foot to vary with the leg position, and for there to be springs in series with the motor, "cushioning" the applied forces. We developed design rules for implementing the variable transmission ratios and springs via a cable transmission with non-round pulleys and stretchable cables, reducing the number of parts required in the leg construction.

 

3. Mass distribution. Mass distribution in the leg has some obvious effects on efficiency (e.g. weight at the foot takes more energy to move than weight close to the hip. It also has more subtle effects, such as making the leg more inclined to swing along some paths than along others. We developed a set of mathematical and design tools for understanding and using these effects to make the "natural" motion of the leg match desired swing patterns.

 

4. Robust control. Much control planning for legs starts by optimizing the leg motion for efficiency on smooth, hard surfaces, and then adds extra control rules to stabilize the system if it encounters uneven or soft terrain. These rules are often hard to define, because they must be overlaid on a baseline motion that was locked in under the assumption of ideal conditions. We have developed a control approach that reverses this ordering, taking maximizing the ability to handle unknown, non-ideal ground conditions as a primary objective, and then finding efficient motions from within this known-safe set of motions. This new safety-first approach offers significant benefits towards the operation of legged robots in locations where humans are also present.
